text.__SUMMARY__: Vanilla walkeriae is a species of vanilla orchid native to India and Sri Lanka. It grows in forest and jungle habitat. It is considered to be a rare species.
text.Description: This species is an epiphyte with thick, succulent, rooting stems up to 15 meters long that climbs on trees and shrubs. The lance-shaped leaves are up to 3.7 centimeters long. The inflorescence is a large raceme of many flowers. The flower can be up to 6.8 centimeters wide and has wavy-edged white petals. The fruit is a thin capsule up to 15 centimeters long.The scientific name commemorates Anna Maria Walker of Sri Lanka with whom Robert Wight collaborated.
text.Uses: The plant is used in the traditional veterinary medicine practices of the Irulas in India. Stem paste is fed to cattle to treat fever and as a nutritional supplement.
text.Conservation: The species is threatened by commercial overexploitation and habitat destruction.
text.External links: Vanilla walkeriae illustration. Swiss Orchid Foundation.
